Okay I used the Arpanet as early at 1976 or 1977 and I helped to invent the Internet writing perhaps the first TCP/IP for the IBM PC in 1983-4.
That project became the billion-dollar company "FTP Software" because FTP requires 2 x TCP's to communication, and only mine could do that.
One thing is missing from this relatively good video.
What Tim Berners-Lee invented was okay but it was a read-only internet, not terribly useful.
It was just a little better than "Gopher" a text-based browser on bulletin boards from U-Minnesota (1990) without fonts & pictures.
People tend to underestimate the importance of Berners-Lee's URLs which name a particular protocol + resource path - THAT was important.
Mark Andreeson greatly expanded the Internet by enhancing the POST operator with cookies (=shopping carts) and forms and this allowed E-Commerce, using the Netscape Browser, circa 1995.

The history of the Internet begins with the development of electronic computers in the 1950s. Initial concepts of wide area networking originated in several computer science laboratories in the United States, United Kingdom, and France.[1] The U.S. Department of Defense awarded contracts as early as the 1960s, including for the development of the ARPANET project, directed by Robert Taylor and managed by Lawrence Roberts. The first message was sent over the ARPANET in 1969 from computer science Professor Leonard Kleinrock's laboratory at University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) to the second network node at Stanford Research Institute(SRI).

Packet switching networks such as the NPL network, ARPANET, Merit Network, CYCLADES, and Telenet, were developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s using a variety of communications protocols.[2] Donald Davies first demonstrated packet switching in 1967 at the National Physics Laboratory(NPL) in the UK, which became a testbed for UK research for almost two decades.[3][4] The ARPANET project led to the development of protocols for internetworking, in which multiple separate networks could be joined into a network of networks.

The Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP) was developed by Robert E. Kahn and Vint Cerf in the 1970s and became the standard networking protocol on the ARPANET, incorporating concepts from the French CYCLADES project directed by Louis Pouzin. In the early 1980s the NSF funded the establishment for national supercomputing centers at several universities, and provided interconnectivity in 1986 with the NSFNETproject, which also created network access to the supercomputer sites in the United States from research and education organizations. Commercial Internet service providers (ISPs) began to emerge in the very late 1980s. The ARPANET was decommissioned in 1990. Limited private connections to parts of the Internet by officially commercial entities emerged in several American cities by late 1989 and 1990,[5] and the NSFNET was decommissioned in 1995, removing the last restrictions on the use of the Internet to carry commercial traffic.

In the 1980s, research at CERN in Switzerland by British computer scientist Tim Berners-Leeresulted in the World Wide Web, linking hypertext documents into an information system, accessible from any node on the network.[6] Since the mid-1990s, the Internet has had a revolutionary impact on culture, commerce, and technology, including the rise of near-instant communication by electronic mail, instant messaging, voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) telephone calls, two-way interactive video calls, and the World Wide Web with its discussion forums, blogs, social networking, and online shopping sites. The research and education community continues to develop and use advanced networks such as JANET in the United Kingdom and Internet2 in the United States. Increasing amounts of data are transmitted at higher and higher speeds over fiber optic networks operating at 1 Gbit/s, 10 Gbit/s, or more. The Internet's takeover of the global communication landscape was almost instant in historical terms: it only communicated 1% of the information flowing through two-way telecommunications networks in the year 1993, already 51% by 2000, and more than 97% of the telecommunicated information by 2007.[7] Today the Internet continues to grow, driven by ever greater amounts of online information, commerce, entertainment, and social networking. However, the future of the global internet may be shaped by regional differences in the world.[8]

People who claim ARPANET is the bread and butter that is the internet, and USA more or less alone made the internet, can arguably be correct if more than one or all of the following conditions are met :
-Only USA or USA and a few countries were using it
-Only a few or no private citizens outside academic and governmental backgrounds had access to it
-It would have no "webpages"
-It would not have youtube/google

I could add more conditions, but these are perhaps the most pertinent ones, but the internet we have today, is thanks to international efforts; it's dumb to argue totally against it! It also boils a lot down to what you define internet as, as well! And besides, most technology is virtually always based on some other technology that isn't necessarily from the same country/region. USA contributed a lot to what became the internet, but not all of it!
But then governments and corporations began exploiting it and made it instead a tool of communication and progress, a tool of stagnation.

The first workable prototype of the Internet came in the late 1960s with the creation of ARPANET, or the Advanced Research Projects Agency Network. Originally funded by the U.S. Department of Defense, ARPANET used packet switching to allow multiple computers to communicate on a single network. Designed as a computer version of the nuclear bomb shelter, ARPAnet protected the flow of information between military installations by creating a network of geographically separated computers that could exchange information via a newly developed ptechnology called NCP or Network Control Protocol.
ARPA stands for the Advanced Research Projects Agency, a branch of the military that developed top secret systems and weapons during the Cold War. U.S. Taxpayer funded Internet that is your creator.

I say:

Overstated British/French contributions and downplayed American contributions. Packet switching was indeed invented by Americans and so was (for the most part) TCP/IP. And the first message sent over the network that would become the internet was between two computers in California at research universities, UCLA (my alma mater) and Stanford. Tim Berners-Lee must be respected for HTTP and HTML of course but Americans really paved the way in terms of infrastructure.  And yes we really did make this thing as a communications backup in case Soviet missiles destroyed the telephone network. Thanks.

How internet was made? some kind of machine that works 24/7 or something?

Back in the days of modems, it used to cost long distance fees to call places not that far away. (ex. 20 miles) Instead of making the call directly, you could call a computer not long distance, half way to the destination (10 miles away), and have it call into the long distance location for free (because it was local to that computer). Messaging systems, like arpanet, would utilitze this way of free calling through computer bulletin boards, and the hardware just became dedicated over time and through commercialization. With computers placed not too far apart, you could basically call anywhere for free... Wahlah! The internet... Basically came about to avoid the high price of long distance telephone calls... Larger companies would pay a lump sum to the phone company to have unlimited telephone access into another area where they might have another site or headquarters and found it cheaper to relay messages by them being more compact than a voice transmission. This, along with consumer interests, invented the internet, but there's no real inventor, it naturally progressed to that stage by it evolving... Sure some companies invested more than others, but they didn't 'invent' anything, it all came about to avoid long distance telephone fees... It then became commercialized, to many people's dismay, and now you pay for internet access through a 'provider'... Which, used to be free just by placing a local telephone call... It was much slower (based off modem speeds), but was entirely free at that time...
I remember buying my first modem. It was 300 baud, and cost over $550.00. I used to run a bulletin board, and it would regularly call other locations and deposit mail messages onto those systems, which, in turn, would relay it further down the line for the messages to reach their final destinations.. without calling long-distance.. It was a clever way to beat the telephone company...

Bulletin Board Systems
private parties allowed people to register username on privately owner computer system

remotely accessing your desktop through the modem
registration was equivalent of giving someone the PIN to your answering machine

and they could add outgoing messages
basically post a topic
and next person trying to call would get busy signal.
eventually that person would log out.. and another person could add their comments.

multiple line systems.. like a business might have with 10 phone lines were very rare
but were among the dozens of BBS systems.. sysop system owner operator.
most asked for small donation
and those that stayed logged in too long hogging access were blocked from logging in ever again.

those BBS systems interlinked like 800 numbers.. 1000s of callers all being logged in at same time on same BBS
eventually linking the individual sysop's into the web as you know it.

The American government invented the internet, and a British guy "invented" the World Wide Web. But it's not shocking that a british narrator doesn't want to give America any credit. Pretty typical.

This video was just straight up misinformation. The internet is the underlying technology that transmits data. The web is, essentially, most, but not all of the data that is transmitted via the internet. You can use the internet without the web, you cannot use the web without the internet. The internet is very clearly the more important invention. The web is pretty much just code that is used to organize data that is transmitted on the internet and then display it in an interface in a web browser. The web is the facade, the internet is the inner workings.
Again, I said it before, but Tim Berners-Lee was just a code monkey. His code was chosen to become the standard of internet communication but he didn't even invent his hypertext code, he imitated the work of the American who did. People give him way too much credit. People constantly say he invented the internet, he didn't.

The internet is an American invention. That's just a fact. People who deny that are either misinformed or dishonest.

I mean there were no youtube back then. Napster was the fad of the day with file sharing, which spawned shit like Limewire & Kazaa. What does Timothy Berners-Lee have to do with the invention of the internet?  Nothing.  It's quite hilarious, then, that this video goes out of its way to single him out (and make mention that he's a Brit), yet they completely ignore who actually invented the primary components of the Internet. 

Let me give you a hint: Americans Robert Metcalfe and David Boggs, inventors of Ethernet (this is what physically attaches computers to the network), and who invented the protocol used to communicate over Ethernet, AKA TCP/IP Americans Vint Cerf and Bob Kahn.  Everything else is just an application that runs over the internet, i.e. HTTP, FTP, RDP, SSH, etc. and isn't relevant unless you're a butthurt former imperial power.

Excellent video -- I haven't heard the term "packet-switching" used since I studied data communication (toward my Computer/Information Science degree some 27 years ago).  The one thing the narrator missed, however, was that ARPA (Advanced Research Projects Agency) was a US Dept. of Defense initiative. This agency researched and developed technologies (Hardware, software, network topologies, data encryption, data formats such as data framing, etc.) inevitably leading to what was then known as DARPAnet. Yes, one of it's main purposes was to allow any data communications to be preserved and received by to its intended receiver in case any part of the data communication networks were attacked (including nuclear) during transmission. This was performed by packet switching and multiple broadcasting of the data packets (frames). Basically, break up the message, send it out to multiple computers (aka "servers"), and then reassemble the messages at the receiving end (drop any duplicate packets if already received.) As a high end scenario; A message is sent via 5 separate network lines via multiple channels (or servers if referring to the computers) (ex. "A" "B" "C", "D", and "E").Message sent to those 5 locations, servers A and C and D are blown up. Since B and E survived the attack. The message can be then rebuilt at the intended receiver. Mission accomplished. ARPA and DARPA inevitably were split into 2 separate US Gov't agencies, but were merged back together (and several name changes of the agency between ARPA and DARPA beginning with Bill Clinton). So, in essence, although preservation of data networks under ?nuclear attack" was not a SOLE purpose of the then (D)ARPAnet, it was one of the MOTIVATIONS in which pushed DARPA's work in developing the network. The term "internet" was derived from (as mentioned in the video) Colleges and Universities to be able to share their info through the networks - but at that time it was a "private" network. It was not until the late 1980's when the network (internet) was opened up to public/commercial enterprises (hence the internet as we now know it today). Although the USA may not have been the sole "inventor" of the internet (and infrastructure), it certainly had very strong influence on how it developed.

Not entirely inaccurate, but the contribution of DARPA was downplayed for some unexplained reason, and the web played up a bit more than I think it needed to be. TCP was a huge step forward and the entire backbone of the internet depends on it to this day. That technology was developed by DARPA (U.S. Dept. of Defense research group). The internet was healthy and growing rapidly well before HTTP was invented. Gopher was our web back then, and it connected computers through hyperlinks well enough for the time. Growth was exploding already when HTTP came along (and would have happened with or without it). It was an evolutionary step taken at the right time. I got the feeling the producers of this video were motivated politically to downplay DARPA's development of TCP.
